text: - [Ramesh] Hello, my name is Ramesh
and I'm a senior product manager with AWS.
- [Lakshmi] And my name is Lakshmi,

Senior Analytics Solutions
Architect at AWS.
- Hi, I'm Joel.

I'm a Principal Specialist
Solution Architect,
Data and Analytics.
- [Ramesh] We are really excited to share

that Amazon DataZone now
expands its data analysis
and visualization option

by adding authentication
support via Amazon,
Athena JDBC driver.
This means data consumers can, easily,

query their project
subscribed data lake assets

in Amazon DataZone, using
popular BI and analytics tools,
like Tableau, PowerBI, Excel,
Excel workbench, DV Weaver, and many more.
Data analysts and scientists can access

and analyze, govern data using
the tool of their choice.

As you know, Amazon DataZone
is a data management service
that helps data consumer easily find

and subscribe to data
from multiple sources

via a single project and then
analyze it using native tools,
like Athena, Redshift, and SageMaker.

Beyond these native tools,
our customers needed a way
to access their govern data in DataZone
to partner analytics solutions,
like Tableau and Spotfire for reporting
or using a compute environment such

as Dominoes on Amazon
EC2, another popular SQL

and BI tools like SQL
Workbench and PowerBI.

Now with this new JDBC
connectivity feature,
user can simply download
and install the latest Athena JDBC driver
for their preferred tool,

make a connection using
a JDBC connection string,

which can be copy pasted from
the Amazon DataZone portal.

Once connected, user can
then ready and visualize

and share data all governed
by Amazon DataZone,

using the tool they
already know and trust.

In this demo, we are going
to walk you through how

to connect various analytics
tool to Amazon DataZone,
using the Athena JDBC driver.
By the end, you will see how easy it is
to access your subscribed data
within your DataZone project,
no matter which tool you prefer.
- [Joel] I would like to show you,

how we can use jointly
data zone with Tableau.
I'm part of the marketing team.
I'm a marketing analyst and I would like
to use my sales data in Tableau
for further analysis.

So first of all, in
DataZone in my project,
I have subscribed to my sales data
that is available within my project.
I've subscribed to this data.
From DataZone, what I would like

to get is all the information
to connect with Tableau,
so I can click on connect on JDBC.
And from there

I can get some parameters
that will be used
to connect DataZone with Tableau.

Those parameters, first option
can be used into a file,
which is Athena properties,

which contain all those
information and domain ID,
the work group that is used by Tableau

to connect my data zone
environment with Tableau
and the Athena property file is included

into the folder data
sources of Tableau desktop.

So using that in Tableau,
I can select Amazon Athena.
I just keep the standard information

because all the parameters
have been included

into Athena properties and
I can click on sign in.
Once I click on sign in,
Tableau is able to retrieve my connection
and I can select the catalog,
my database and I can retrieve my table.
And from there I can start my analysis.
That's the first option.
The second option that can be used is

to click on connect with
JDBC, copy the JDBC URL.
And from there I can go on Tableau

and use another option,
which is the option two.
I select other database JDBC.

I copy paste the URL into
URL, I keep the information,

I leave the default
parameters in this window
and I click on sign in, the schema,
and that's it.
The same, I can retrieve my table
and I can start also as well, my analysis.

So two option, either using
the Athena JDBC driver
with the Athena property file

or option two, using the
other JDBC connection
and using the URL.

Depending the performance
and the easiness,

you can select either
option one or option two.
- [Lakshmi] Now let's understand,

how the data analysts run
exploratory data analysis.
using the SQL client engine DBeaver
and consume the subscribed data product
from Amazon DataZone.
In the DBeaver SQL client engine,
create a new database connection
and select the Athena driver.

In the driver properties,
enter the parameters captured

from the environment configuration
from the DataZone portal.

Once the parameters are
entered, test the connection
and a new web browser will be launched,
which will redirect
to the IM identity center sign in portal.
Enter your login credentials

and provide consent to
authorize DataZone plugin.

This authorizes DBeaver
to access data zone.
Once the connection is initiated,
it gives a message which indicates
that the connection is live.
And now the data analysts

from the marketing team
can successfully query,
all the subscribed data assets
from DBeaver SQL client engine.
Thank you for watching the demo.
